content.raw:
Using yi-hao's test script from issue 2120, it looks like there's still some inconsistency between the number of pixels along the x and y directions:


```
#!python

import yt

ds = yt.load("GasSloshing/sloshing_nomag2_hdf5_plt_cnt_0150")

slice = yt.SlicePlot(ds, 'x', "density", width = (100.0, 'kpc'))
slice.set_buff_size((8,4))
slice.save()
```

Which produces: http://i.imgur.com/mp770iB.png

I would expect the image to have 8 pixels along the x direction and 4 along y.
content.html:
Using yi-hao's test script from issue 2120, it looks like there's still some inconsistency between the number of pixels along the x and y directions:

import yt

ds = yt.load("GasSloshing/sloshing_nomag2_hdf5_plt_cnt_0150")

slice = yt.SlicePlot(ds, 'x', "density", width = (100.0, 'kpc'))
slice.set_buff_size((8,4))
slice.save()

Which produces: http://i.imgur.com/mp770iB.png

I would expect the image to have 8 pixels along the x direction and 4 along y.

content.raw: Maybe the fix is as simple as reversing size here?
content.html: Maybe the fix is as simple as reversing size here?

content.html: thank you for writing this down

content.html: This might be useful for alpha-compositing images together :)

content.raw: Yup, especially from overlapping multiblock data! :)
content.html: Yup, especially from overlapping multiblock data! :)

content.raw:
Besides the flake8 failure, almost all of the failures are due to single pixel-level shifts and are fine. One of them is a big improvement: https://tests.yt-project.org/job/yt_py27/828/testReport/junit/yt.visualization.tests/test_plotwindow/test_attributes_wt_3/

I'd be fine with just incrementing the answer number.

content.raw:
I've merged and responded to a couple comments, but I'm going to be issuing a separate PR to add tests for the pixelization calls (not plot window) for cylindrical and spherical meshes.  Then those answers can be generated, and these compared.  @yihaochen has one point that I'm not sure about (I have tested and I get the same results as before the PR for the test cases I've checked) but otherwise, I think once the tests go in this will be ready to go in.

If I can get this one reviewed, then once the forthcoming one goes in, I'll have this one ready.

Then those answers can be generated, and these compared. Yi-Hao Chen has one point that I'm not sure about (I have tested and I get the same results as before the PR for the test cases I've checked) but otherwise, I think once the tests go in this will be ready to go in.

If I can get this one reviewed, then once the forthcoming one goes in, I'll have this one ready.

content.raw: I thought ```pi``` is the pixel index in x direction (line 384) and should be compared with ```buff.shape[1]```. And line 388 shoould be ```buff[pj, pi] = field[i]```. Did I misunderstand something here?
content.html: I thought pi is the pixel index in x direction (line 384) and should be compared with buff.shape[1]. And line 388 shoould be buff[pj, pi] = field[i]. Did I misunderstand something here?

content.raw: No, it's likely my misunderstanding, so I will investigate again.
content.html: No, it's likely my misunderstanding, so I will investigate again.

description:
This changes the main pixelization routines to accept input buffers.

One of the biggest impediments to multi-block systems is the way that
pixelizers currently allocate their own buffers.  This allows them to receive
input buffers.

I have changed, likely incorrectly, rows/cols in some of these pixelizers (cc
@yihaochen ) to be more consistent.

While I think the "work" here is done, this isn't ready to go in until after
feature freeze is over and until after Yi-Hao and I work through the rows/cols
issues.

UPDATE 1: Merging with upstream, and correcting my confusion about who issued the row/column PR.  Many apologies.
